title: AI and the Future of Health with Joelle Barral

rawLines.text: I'm hoping AI contributes to, you know,
bringing back the joy of practice in
medicine. So, wait, it actually works
then? You record a cough and it can tell
you if you've got TB in shorts. Yes. By
combining those modalities, by getting
to a deeper understanding at the
cellular level of what's going on, we'll
finally be able to crack, you know, for
example, triple negative breast cancers
or more advanced cancers that today we
don't have good good solutions for. Are
you concerned that people are trying to
diagnose themselves with generative AI?
Yeah, I mean I would say even before you
really shouldn't do that, right? Like
you shouldn't play your own doctor.
Welcome back to Google Deep Mind the
podcast. I'm Professor Hannah Fry. In
this episode, I'm talking to Joel Bal,
senior director of research at Google
DeepMind about AI for health. Now, for
years we have joked about how the
internet is the hypochondriac's best
friend, capable of turning a small
headache into a terminal illness and
vice versa with a quick search and a
click of a button. But quietly, behind
the scenes, the role of algorithms in
medical care has been shifting. We've
already talked a lot on this podcast
about the impact of AI on drug discovery
and research into proteins, but now AI
promises to change diagnosis and
treatment, too. Welcome to the podcast,
Charles. I mean, there have been some
pretty big changes already with AI.
Should we expect that healthcare will
look very different in 10 or 15 years
time to how it looks now? Absolutely. I
believe so. I think healthcare is really
posed to be drastically changed with AI
but it may not look too different. Um I
like to think of or at least I picture
healthcare as a fairly sticky ecosystem
you know so 10 15 years from now um we
will likely still go to our primary care
doctor and then you know um follow
through with specialist visits etc. Um
but each of them is going to be
augmented if you wish by by an AI agent.
So underneath the system will be very
different. Uh but it may not appear as
different from what we know today. How
long have you been working in AI in
healthcare? Oh wow. My my whole career I
would say I was still a student when um
I think it was CS 229 right the the
class on machine learning was was taking
off. Um and I remember you know working
with um I was further along in my PhD
but working with with students on how to
segment the larynx right and and and AI
was you know this new tool that could
really help us do that better and I
haven't stopped ever since but but why
this area for you I mean what's the
appeal of it for you in healthcare
you're always challenged right like
there are lots of things that we don't
do that well or you don't have infinite
data and so and so you're never perfect
so you're always trying to to leverage
the best tools to to do what you're
trying to do. Um, and then I I joined
Google a decade ago to work on surgical
robotics. And I remember vividly it was
the beginning of us uh really realizing
that with images anything that a human
could do in terms of interpreting those
images machines were going to be able to
do. And so I I sat down with with my my
surgeon colleague and and we took a
hundred uh colistctomies which are you
know when you remove the gallbladder uh
we manually segmented um livers and gall
bladders and and I fed you know a pretty
simple uh neural net to see whether you
know the algorithm would be able to to
decifer between those two things and I
remember being incredibly surprised
actually when it did that perfectly
because most of the other tools we had
at our disposal were never perfect right
like It did the job, but not always.
Now, you know, livers and galbutters
really don't look the same. It's a very
easy task. Like any student will be able
to tell you which one is which. But but
still, right? Like that really for meant
okay, now we have something that will be
infinitely more powerful than you know
any of the the algorithms I I I had been
working on previously. And people
forget, right? But when I was still a
student, we didn't know like it was hard
with computer vision to decipher a QR
code, right? Like that was where we were
uh back then. And so again, AI has
really opened up
um a world uh of capabilities uh far
beyond anything we could envision
before. Okay. Well, let's start off with
some of the examples of of of places
where AI has already made a lot of
headway. I'm thinking about diagnosis
here and and maybe medical imaging in
particular. Talk to me a bit about
what's been going on. Yeah, we've seen a
lot of that over the last 10 years.
That's what we typically call narrow AI.
Narrow because it's it's solving one
task, right? You you mentioned medical
imaging. So, you can take a chest X-ray
or an MRI or we've done also like u
diabetic retinopathy uh work. Those are
already tools that have been um FDA
cleared for example and deployed in the
clinic and they are um augmenting
radiologists in the sense that for those
specific tasks um the machine does a
pretty damn good job at um at at
annotating the image for the physician.
Let me make sure I understand this then.
Okay. So so if we take diabetic
retinopathy as an example, this is
people have diabetes and potentially
it's a cause of blindness. Is that
right? Absolutely. It's the leading
cause of preventable blindness worldwide
and uh it's pretty simple. So you take
an image of the back of the eye um with
a fundus camera and that gives you um an
image of the retina that then
ofthmologists will grade on a scale from
1 to five um to indicate uh whether
patients have no disease, moderate
disease or se severe disease. And um
what was striking when we when we
started working on that particular
problem was the fact that uh it was
actually really hard to get to what we
call ground truth. Meaning you know as
we're training our machine learning
models um to learn a task we first need
to provide them with a set of of ground
truth images that that that means the
the pairs of the image and the label.
And um for that particular task, you
know, we asked maybe one, two, three of
themologists and often we got different
answers. And I think one thing we did
particularly well was to be very
rigorous in in trying to establish
ground truth. And so we ended up working
with 5050 of themologists and we
realized that actually on on some images
um they really didn't agree with each
other, right? They could they some would
have given one two three like each one
of the scores could have could have
potentially been the diagnosis a patient
would have received because patients
only see one right they don't go and and
and have their images graded by 50 times
boy so some opthalmologists would say
this is a mild or no disease and others
would say all the way up to severe on
the same image precisely which sometimes
is not too surprising meaning that you
know most opthalmologists and that's
true for most physicians see what what's
in their community And um and the rare
cases by definition they don't see them
very often. So it it can get very hard
to to properly annotate an image if you
don't see that type very often. Well,
how do you do that then if even the
experts don't agree? How do you decide
what the correct answer is? Well, that's
exactly why we had to go to 50, right?
Then you have this consensus among all
of themologists and then sometimes you
go to even uh deeper experts, right? to
really get to what is the correct label
for that image and that way you properly

know we also did a lot of rigorous
testing to make sure that we had
algorithms in which we could I mean
which we could trust. But then I suppose
on the flip side of that even though
that makes the labeling quite difficult.
If you know that experts are disagreeing
then actually you can create something
that is a new gold standard really like
better than than than experts.
Absolutely. And I think that's where the
AI has really its role to play, right?
It's where for tasks that it is really
good at that are really not not very
easy to be done by a single um human. I
seem to remember reading this paper

images for other things than just

the model performed better than flipping

I do think for um indications of of

that can be a useful uh tool because if
you're going to do that screening for
diabetic retinopathy
anyway, but now you have a test that can
also provide you with additional
information. Um, you know, you could

So indeed, and it was, you know, kind of
both interesting interestingly
scientifically to realize that u those

with potentially also applications that

you know in in radiology there's this

because it's very often that if you know
if you screen me head to toe with with
MRI right now you'll find things you
know you'll find nodules things that are
abnormal they will get me worried but
actually we never did clinical trials to
see whether having that thing somewhere
is good or bad right and many people
leave for with those things forever
without any issues so you don't really
want to do that type of screening that
will you get everyone worried. Um and
the other thing I would say is um when
you do a blood test, you do a blood test
for a very particular thing, right?
You're not um as the you know the lab
who did the the blood test for finding a
particular v virus is not responsible
for checking everything, right? And if
they haven't noticed that you had
something else that wasn't what you know
you got blood drawn, they're not
responsible for that. And so it's it's
for for imaging it's always a little
ambiguous to um what to do with those
incidental findings, right? And for
those aspects of narrow AI maybe
um I think the jury is still out whether
or not you know that will we want the AI
to always look for everything else when
it's looking at one particular image. Uh
even if it could provide pretty helpful
alarms. Those are images that we've
spoken about, but are there other other
inputs that you can use for this very
narrow AI type of diagnosis? Absolutely.
Um, all I would say all types of of
modalities, right? We've done a lot of
uh very interesting work uh with sound
for example leveraging sound to be able
to detect uh tuberculosis look from
cough and and people have also um
explored that quite a bit uh during co
obviously um and so we see um you know
good biomarkers actually in in sound
that can help also provide um some
relatively cheap ways to uh diagnose
those types of TCSS. So wait, it
actually works then. You record a cough
and it can tell you if you've got TB in

Okay. But there are limitations to this
stuff though, right? I
mean, are they getting it right every

know, a a very good point with uh like
with any algorithms, right? There is
sensitivity and specificity. So it can
have either false positives, false false
negatives. So thinking that something
exists when it doesn't or or missing
something that it should have uh picked.
Um in general though what we you know
what we what we do and what we did with
the diabetic rhnopathy paper is um
really checking how it does with respect

they can decide that really they cannot
um afford uh false alarms or the other

missing anything. But you know in both
cases I think you know for an algorithm
to be to be cleared by regulatory

an algorithm could say that it's TB when

TV TV and and and say that it was fine.
And obviously you don't want either of

percentage accuracy almost are you

that same population. If you're

we've already screened 700,000 people in

So Thailand is one of those countries in

is fairly large, right? There are many
